item.title: The Sabbat School Class, Lesson 10: What About You?
item.description:
There is one question which almost everyone who has any desire for the spiritual has probably asked at least once, and I asked it many times. You hear about someone else's spiritual experience and, unless you are already having equal experiences, the natural tendency is to ask that question: "What about me?"

It's only natural to want such experience, and it's to be expected that you might wonder why it can happen for someone else but not you. But why can't it happen for you?

There's a story that Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart sat down at a harpsichord at age six and immediately began playing what became known as the Minuet In G. Well, if that story is true, that was Mozart, not Aidan Odinson and not you, either. If either of us were to sit at such a keyboard and begin to attempt music, most folks would probably suggest that we take music lessons.

Music lessons are simply mentored practice sessions which occur in between series of our own practice sessions where we make music which gradually sounds more musical.

While we might not need mentored practice sessions in spirituality, there are things we can do to help ourselves, beginning with our visualizations. And from there, much can happen.

Blessed Be!

There's a story that Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart sat down at a harpsichord at age six and immediately began playing what became known as the Minuet In G. Well, if that story is true, that was Mozart, not Aidan Odinson and not you, either. If either of us were to sit at such a keyboard and begin to attempt music, most folks would probably suggest that we take music lessons.
Music lessons are simply mentored practice sessions which occur in between series of our own practice sessions where we make music which gradually sounds more musical.
While we might not need mentored practice sessions in spirituality, there are things we can do to help ourselves, beginning with our visualizations. And from there, much can happen.
Blessed Be!

item.title: February 20, 2010 - Mass For The Shut-Out In Honor of Tempest Smith
item.description:
Tempest Kayne Smith died on February 20, 2001. She had been the victim of religious harassment and bullying. It was after her diary was discovered that people learned the extent and severity of the bullying she was put through.

Sticks and stones might break our bones, but those are wounds which can heal. The wounds caused by words are not so easy to heal, and sometimes it seems that they just don't heal.

I won't criticize Tempest for how she died or anything about her death. I have enough memories of my own life at age twelve to know better than to "Monday morning quarterback".

In the United States of America, people claim that there is religious freedom. It didn't work that way for her - and the last I heard, Lincoln Park, Michigan is within the United States. And we've heard enough about bullying, including a recent case in Seattle in which police refused to help a young woman who knew she was in danger, and then so-called security guards stood around and watched as she was beaten.

Tempest Smith's classmates, the ones who should have been her friends, wrote many apologies which were on display at her funeral.

I see her as a martyr. I also see her as a patron for religious freedom and for victims of bullying.

Blessed Be!

item.title: The Sabbat School Class, Lesson 8: Thinking about Tempest Smith Day coming
item.description:
Tempest Smith Day is February 20th.

Tempest Kayne Smith was intelligent and creative. She played the flute, wrote poetry, and sometimes showed an intelligence and sensitivity beyond that normally associated with someone her age. She died on February 20, 2001.

She died by her own hand, after the harassment, taunts and teasing by her classmates had become such torment that she could take no more. They harassed her because she was a Wiccan. She was a Wiccan by her own choice.

After she passed, a diary was found in which she wrote about the daily torments. Crowds of her classmates singing "Jesus loves you" at her were among the few that I can describe here and retain my "general audiences" rating.

And this was in a school in the United States, where schoolteachers talk about how the United States has religious freedom. It somehow did not work that way for Tempest Smith.

And so, we commemorate her. And think of the others like her whom we might not know about. And so that we can resolve that it not happen again.

Blessed Be!

item.title: February 2, 2010 - Mass For The Shut-Out - Imbolc Celebration!
item.description:
It's time to celebrate Imbolc!

Inbolc is one of the least-known but most-worthwhile celebrations in the cycle of the year, especially because of the fact that it is a fulfillment of the promise made at Samhain.

Remember Samhain? At that time, there was a death but also the promise that an ending by definition means a new beginning, and that new beginning was promised to us! At Yule, what we see as the sun beginning its return journey is marked appropriately in many spiritual paths by the celebration of the birth of a divine child.

For a child born at Yule, we could see Imbolc as the naming done in some paths, or the Briss in the Jewish tradition. In the mundane world, Imbolc's coming is announced by the first plants sticking their fresh sprouts through the snow, and the animals who were cared for over the winter giving birth.

Above all, it is another fulfillment of the promise made by The Divine, on the way to the complete fulfillment shared by Ostara and Beltaine.

Blessed Be!

item.title: December 21, 2009: Mass For The Shut-Out - Celebrating Yule!
item.description:
It is time to celebrate Yule!

Yule is indeed just possibly the most primary and basic of all of the Sabbats, and almost every spiritual path has a celebration at the time of the Winter Solstice which has the basic theme of a new birth, and especially a divine birth. Even Hannukah can be seen that way, if you understand it as the re-opening and re-consecration of the Temple at Jerusalem after the exile in Babylon. In fact, there indeed is a re-birth after what some had thought was a death. And that's the original idea. Yule was when the sun stopped its rertreat away from us and began its return journey and with it the promise of another spring and summer.

And I see the birth at Yule as being Samhain's gift. It's much the same was as what a seed does in order to become a tree. And so, there is new life, and a new promise.
And that's what Yule is giving us. The beginning of the fulfillment of the promise made at Samhain.
Blessed Be!

item.title: The Sabbat School Class, Lesson 6: A Yule Gift - Something You Can Actually Do!
item.description:
This lesson is one that you might see as being a Yule gift.

One of the most often-asked questions where spiritual matters are concerned is the basic question of what can you do. People spend a major part of their lives searching for something to do about whatever concerns them, and here is an offering for you which might help.

Between the spiritually walking wounded, those who have come to realize that what they were taught doesn't seem to work anymore, and those who simply want to see if there is anything more, there are enough people to fill many churches and keep many clergy very busy. The problem is helping them find the answers which they seek, and everyone's answers are unique to that person.

To borrow from the jargon of systems analysts and MBA's, what's needed is to "think outside of the box".

And that's what we're discussing here.

Blessed Be!

item.title: The Sabbat School Class, Lesson 5: Things To Do With Bread And Wine
item.description:
And here, perhaps, you'll find some answers as to what I'm doing in Mass For The Shut-Out, and more importantly, how you can apply them in what you do spiritually.

The roots go beyond Crowley's Gnostic Mass, The Mass, Passover Seder, or Cakes and Ale. One of the most ancient references is in the Old Testament, in Genesis when Melchizidek, who was both a king and a priest, met Abram (not Abraham yet) and greeted him with bread and wine. And that tells us that bread and wine must have been a well-established custom by that time, which we would know as the Bronze Age.

It's also worth noting that in so many of the rites based on bread and wine, the Pagan/Wiccan aspects are there for anyone with the knowledge of where to look and the wisdom to know what to acknowledge. Anyone want to guess why a Roman Catholic priest makes the sign of the cross over the chalice? Might it harken back to the days when a Norse Vitki or Ghodi (or Vitka or Ghoda) would make the sign of Thor's Hammer over a similar vessel (or a drinking horn, for that matter)?

So much to explore, and so much to learn. And you can put it all to use for your own benefit, too! Enjoy this exploration!

Blessed Be!

item.description:
I was invited to join the House of Independent Bishops, and of course I accepted.

And what is a Wiccan doing among a bunch of bishops? Quite a lot, actually!

The title "High Priest" is sufficient to be considered to be the equivalent of a bishop, and it also means that I can begin to build my omni-denominational ministry in that direction. In addition to naming The Virtual Mission Chapel Of The Archangel Uriel as a cathedral (even if the "cathedra" is a folding chair), there also can be The Diocese Of The Archangel Uriel, which has no borders and also has no denominations.

A tavern, where the spiritually thirsty may drink. A diner, where the spiritually starving may be fed. A hospital, where the spiritually wounded are healed.

That's what this is all about.

Blessed Be!

item.title: February 20, 2009 - Mass For The Shut-out in honor of Tempest Smith
item.description: Tempest Kayne Smith died on February 20, 2001. She died at the age of twelve years old. She died as a direct result of the religious harassment she received from her school-mates. This did not happen in some third-world country, but in Lincoln Park, Michigan USA. This Eucharist is offered in her honor in hopes of the day when freedom of religion actually includes all religions.
